sen.j: 真義真言宗の教学の祖である興教大師覚鑁の自所。
sen.e: Mitsugon-in Temple was the base of religious activities of Kakuban, who founded "Shingi Shingonshu" (New Shingon Sect of Buddhism) and was posthumously given the title of "Kogyo Daishi" (Great Priest of Prosperous Teachings).
sen.cmt: ・「自所」は国語辞典にも漢和辞典にも存在しない言葉ですが、「活動の拠点」の意味と解して訳しています。
sen.e: Mitsugon-in Temple was the base of religious activities of Kakuban, who founded "Shingi Shingonshu" (New Shingon Sect of Buddhism) and was posthumously given the title of "Kogyo Daishi" (Great Priest of Prosperous Teachings).

sen.j: 覚鑁が、腐敗した金剛峯寺の内紛に憂いを持ち、密厳院において３余年に及ぶ無言行を敢行した直後に書き上げたと言われる密厳院発露懺悔文は有名。
sen.e: Kakuban deplored the internal conflict seen in the corrupt Kongobu-ji Temple, so he implemented "mugon no gyo" (the discipline of not talking) for more than three years, and just after the discipline, he is said to have written at a stretch well-known "Mitsugon-in Hotsuro Sange no Mon" (Religious Confession at Mitsugon-in Temple).

sen.j: 高野山一の橋から奥の院に向かう途中に位置する。
sen.e: Mitsugon-in Temple is located along the way that runs from Ichinohashi to Okunoin (Ichinohashi and Okunoin are both on Mt. Koya, and Okunoin is the name of the place at which the mausoleum of Kukai is situated).

sen.j: 覚鑁が密厳院にて本尊とした不動明王は、運慶作である平常眼の不動明王であった。
sen.e: The "Fudo Myoo" (Acala, one of the Five Wisdom Kings) which Kakuban worshipped as the main statue of Mitsugon-in Temple was crafted by Unkei, and it has ordinary eyes.
sen.cmt: ・「平常眼」というのは、不動明王の眼が多くの場合怒りの表情をたたえていることとの対比において、「普通のまなざしをしていること」を指していると思われます。

sen.e: In 1184, two venerable statues of the Fudo Myoo were made as private Buddhist statues of Tokimasa HOJO.

sen.e: Today, one of them is enshrined in Ganjoju-in Temple in Nirayama, Izu City.

sen.e: Another statue is enshrined secretly in the sanctum of Shincho-ji Temple on Mt. Tokei, situated in Tachikawa City, Tokyo Metropolis.
